Latest Updates https://www.economist.com/latest/ The most recent blogs and online articles from The Economist - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 8 月 1 日，星期二 04:30:07 GMT 120 What if Germany stopped making cars?

“大众品牌的未来岌岌可危。”当大众市场品牌的新任老板托马斯·谢弗 (Thomas Schäfer) 七月初向他的管理团队做演讲时，他并没有粉饰公司的问题。高成本、需求下降、竞争加剧——这样的例子不胜枚举。他警告说：“屋顶着火了。”这呼应了近代商业史上最引人注目的警报之一——斯蒂芬·埃洛普 (Stephen Elop) 的呼声。 2011 年，埃洛普在执掌诺基亚后不久，将自己的公司比作“燃烧的平台”。全球最大的手机制造商。

就诺基亚而言，警钟并没有起到任何作用。几年后，该公司被解散，其手机业务出售给微软，微软随后关闭了该公司。强大的大众汽车、其更强大的母公司（拥有其他九个品牌），甚至德国最强大的工业，真的会遭遇类似的命运吗？如果确实如此，这对欧洲最大的经济体意味着什么？

汽车行业似乎不太可能立即崩溃。 2022 年，按收入计算，大众汽车成为全球最大的汽车制造商，为其提供充足的现金来支持其最大的品牌。 7 月 27 日，该公司报告称，2023 年上半年销售额同比健康增长 18%，达到 1,560 亿欧元（1,740 亿美元）。德国另外两家汽车巨头宝马和梅赛德斯-奔驰的处境也不错。

然而灾难不再是不可想象的。德国实业家对未来感到真正的焦虑。 7月份，智库Ifo研究所的商业信心指数连续第三个月下降。德国老板们赞同谢弗先生的担忧清单，并增加了其他抱怨，从糟糕的官僚主义到对华贸易的微妙地缘政治。

汽车制造商比大多数行业更容易面临这些挑战，因为他们必须同时就多项转型进行谈判。例如，他们必须使车队电气化，并学习开发软件。随着这些趋势的发展，更多的附加值可能来自其他地方。业内人士承认，工厂将不得不收缩甚至关闭，许多供应商也是如此，尤其是那些制造内燃机和变速箱零部件的供应商。

德国汽车工业还必须解决日益严重的中国问题。受益于这个亚洲巨头近几十年来的快速增长——2022年下半年，德国三大汽车公司约40%的收入来自中国——现在却遭遇了命运的逆转。大众汽车刚刚下调了全球交付预期，主要原因是中国销量放缓。地缘政治可能会让事情变得更糟。中国的竞争对手已经开始向海外扩张，特别是在欧洲。去年，中国的汽车出口量首次超过德国：分别约为 300 万辆和 260 万辆。

被逼到灭绝？

所有这些问题都集中在沃尔夫斯堡，这里是大众汽车总部的所在地，也就是谢弗先生所比喻的屋顶。据媒体报道，该集团电动汽车的订单量比计划低 30% 至 70%，具体取决于品牌。该公司仍需解决其软件问题：5 月份，该公司再次对数字部门 Cariad 的管理团队进行了重组。在中国快速增长的电动汽车市场中，大众品牌是一个落伍者，市场份额仅为2%。

汽车制造商潜在消亡的后果取决于你认为这个行业有多大。德国汽车制造业直接雇用的员工不到 90 万，其中三分之二在汽车公司，其余在供应商。这仅占德国劳动力总数的 2% 左右。目前，德国品牌销售的乘用车中有近四分之三是在国外制造的。去年，当地工厂出厂的车辆仅有 350 万辆，大约与 20 世纪 70 年代中期的数量相当。

忧心忡忡的业内人士指出了替代措施。欧盟汽车制造总增加值的一半以上是在德国生产的，远远领先于排名第二的法国，占 9%。汽车占德国出口商品的16%。基尔研究所 (Kiel Institute) 的尼尔斯·扬森 (Nils Jannsen) 计算称，尽管德国汽车工业的经济重要性在 2017 年达到该国总增加值的 4.7%，但到 2020 年（有数据可查的最后一年），这一比例仍为 3.8%。智库。据其他估计，这比日本和韩国等其他汽车制造强国高出约一个百分点。

此外，只关注狭隘的行业数字忽视了该行业对于德国股份公司的真正重要性。 “它可以说是一种操作系统，”伊福工业组织和新技术中心的负责人奥利弗·法尔克 (Oliver Falck) 解释道。 “德国经济及其机构的重要部分依赖于此，”他说。

首先，直接供应商并不是唯一依赖大众汽车及其同行的供应商。最近的数据很难获得，但根据另一家智库IW的托马斯·普尔斯 (Thomas Puls) 等人 2020 年的一项研究，全球对德国汽车的需求占德国金属制造商增加值的 16% 以上。塑料制造商。他们还估计，全球需求间接创造了另外 160 万个就业岗位，使汽车行业支持的总人数达到 250 万人，超过德国劳动力的 5%。

德国的投资和创新与该国的汽车制造商息息相关。 IW 的数据显示，2020 年，汽车行业占制造业固定资本形成总额的 35%。根据主要由研究基金会组成的协会 Stifterverband 的数据，2021 年，该行业占制造业研发总量的 42% 以上，并支付了其他公司和研究机构 64% 的研发费用。 IW的数据显示，2017 年，汽车制造商占企业专利申请量的近一半，高于 2005 年的三分之一。

汽车工业也是德国备受推崇的社会模式的核心。一个重要因素是区域平等。汽车工厂通常建在经济薄弱的地区，沃尔夫斯堡就是最好的例子。该行业支撑着其中许多地区。最近的一项研究显示，德国 400 个市县中有 48 个严重依赖汽车行业的就业机会。沃尔夫斯堡遥遥领先：该市 47% 的工人在该行业工作。该研究的作者之一、研究机构WZB的研究员沃尔夫冈·施罗德 (Wolfgang Schroeder) 表示，如果汽车制造业衰退，德国将面临“许多地方危机”。

如果没有强大的汽车工业，德国总体上平静的劳资关系将变得更加紧张。巴登-符腾堡州是梅赛德斯-奔驰、保时捷和大型汽车零部件供应商博世的所在地，巴登-符腾堡州IG Metall 的负责人罗曼·齐茨尔斯伯格 (Roman Zitzelsberger) 等工会领导人坦率地承认，这是该组织的“支柱”。 IG Metall 拥有约 200 万会员，使其成为世界上最大的单一工会。其中大约三分之一在汽车行业工作。该行业一些公司的工会会员率达到 90%。这种优势反过来又帮助IG Metall 谈判达成良好的工资协议，然后辐射到其地位较弱的其他公司和行业。

汽车工业还巩固了德国的共同决策模式，保证工人在公司董事会中有代表权。大众汽车再次成为最好的例子。该行业强大的工作委员会为IG Metall 提供了获取重要资源（从资金到信息）的途径。公司监事会由 20 名成员组成，其中员工代表占一半，使他们能够定期了解公司状况的最新动态，并有权否决战略决策。 （另外两名成员是来自下萨克森州的政治任命者，该州拥有该集团 12% 的股份。）

工会智库汉斯·伯克勒基金会的经济学家塞巴斯蒂安·杜林认为，如果这种安排破裂，德国劳动力市场的平衡将会改变。他说：“稍微夸张一点，大众汽车能否成功实现转型，或者被特斯拉取代，都会产生很大的影响。”他指的是这家美国电动汽车先驱公司，该公司刚刚宣布打算扩建柏林附近的工厂。前往欧洲最大的汽车工厂。杜利恩表示，随着时间的推移，相对于其他欧洲国家的服务业和制造业工作，德国制造业工作的薪酬将不再特别高。

德国汽车工业衰退对心理的影响更难以衡量，但影响同样深远。德国工业的声誉及其工程实力已经因大众汽车 2015 年的“柴油门”排放作弊丑闻而受到打击，现在将再次受到打击。在去年发表的一篇论文中，圣母大学的 Rüdiger Bachmann 和其他人计算出，由于该公司被发现篡改排放读数，其他德国品牌在美国的销量下降了 166,000 辆汽车，损失了 77 亿美元的收入，或者占 2014 年总数的近四分之一。

换句话说，如果德国的汽车工业消失，这将“在欧洲中部留下一个巨大的经济坑”， WZB的施罗德表示。当然，德国政客们极力不让这种情况发生。柴油门事件之后，他们对该行业的支持不再那么全心全意。但公司汽车的税收减免等补贴并没有消失，这些补贴让员工放弃部分工资来换取高端汽车是值得的。德国超过三分之二的新车是由公司购买的；许多人最终主要是在个人旅行中开车。

在下萨克森州，汽车工业可能太大而不能失败。大众汽车在沃尔夫斯堡以外的五个地方设有工厂。该公司总共在当地雇用了约 130,000 名员工。该州的政治家只需看看隔壁的图林根州，就知道如果该州经济陷入困境会发生什么——大众汽车的崩溃将不可避免。极右翼的德国另类选择党目前在图林根民意调查中以 34% 的支持率领先。

骑进夕阳

这些考虑因素淹没了一些声音，这些声音指出，从长远来看，延长汽车制造商的生命支持可能会适得其反。巴赫曼认为，德国政治家需要对市场力量多一点信心，以填补德国汽车制造业衰落时可能出现的经济空间。 TLGG咨询公司的 Christoph Bornschein 认为，德国的大型汽车工业曾经是一个优势，但现在却越来越拖累该国。 “汽车是德国对机械工程的高度重视的最大体现，”他说。正如大众汽车公司软件部门持续存在的问题所表明的那样，一个经过优化以生产出像发条一样运行的昂贵机械奇迹的经济体系将很难在日益数字化的世界中重塑自己。

一旦汽车行业不再占据主导地位，就会有更多的替代空间。流入该行业的补贴将减少，而更多的资本将流入初创企业。越来越少的德国年轻人会学习机械工程，而更多的人会选择计算机科学。研究人员将投入更多精力，比如开发移动服务，而不是再申请一项与汽车相关的专利。

这种随心所欲的做法对埃因霍温来说是行之有效的。这座荷兰城市曾经由曾经的电子巨头飞利浦主导，就像沃尔夫斯堡由大众汽车主导一样，现在拥有数千家小公司。其中大部分供应ASML ，这是一家先进芯片制造设备制造商，已成为欧洲最有价值的公司之一。埃斯波仍然是诺基亚的总部所在地，该公司如今生产电信网络设备，现在也拥有蓬勃发展的初创生态系统。

诚然，汽车制造比手机等电子产品的短暂生产更为根深蒂固。因此，尤其是如果下降是渐进的，该行业将会适应。博世或大陆集团等大型供应商将更多地为特斯拉等外国汽车制造商工作（据说在这家加州公司成立初期，博世提供了其80%的附加值）。较小的供应商将专业化并提供服务，就像许多中小型企业以前所做的那样。德国可能会停止生产更便宜的汽车，并更加专注于生产少量高利润的豪华汽车。大众汽车甚至可能将自己转变为合同制造商，为其他品牌组装电动汽车，就像富士康为苹果组装 iPhone 一样。

行业内外的一些人已经在想象没有大众汽车的未来，至少现在是这样。另一家研究机构ISF慕尼黑的安德烈亚斯·博斯 (Andreas Boes) 表示，该企业“需要停止只围绕汽车制定战略”。博斯先生领导了一群年轻的汽车行业高管和专家，他们最近发表了一份“移动宣言”。他建议，公司不应该让汽车变得更加舒适，让人们花更多的时间在车上，并可以出售额外的服务，而应该致力于组织整个社会从A到B的能力。大众汽车及其德国汽车制造商一直在帮助人们出行。他们没有理由不继续以聪明的新方式来做这件事。 ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 20:12:03 GMT /内容/nmuvrjfmfkqnp4h6sdibpl5u65q0rbq1 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/31/what-if-germany-stopped-making-cars Quantitative easing has cost hundreds of billions of dollars

全球金融危机爆发以来的十五年里，富裕国家的央行购买了价值数万亿美元的债券，试图刺激经济。现在账单到期了。根据最新统计，美国联邦储备委员会 (Federal Reserve) 的 8.2万亿美元证券投资组合账面损失达 9,110 亿美元。 7 月 25 日，英国央行表示，在合理假设下，财政部将在 2023 年至 2033 年间转移约 2750 亿英镑（3530 亿美元），以弥补银行的现金流出。 7 月 28 日，日本央行将长期债券收益率上限从 0.5% 提高至 1%，令市场感到意外。我们计算出，所有期限的日本债券收益率每上升 0.25 个百分点，央行持有的巨额债券价值将下降约 580 亿美元，相当于日本GDP的 1.5%。

中央银行可以创造货币，因此不会破产。但让他们流失现金会导致通货膨胀，除非纳税人弥补损失。履行这一义务的成本不断上升，因此确定量化宽松（ qe ）是否值得，以及下次经济需要刺激时是否应该使用这种大规模债券购买变得很重要。

为了实施量化宽松，央行在银行体系中以准备金的形式创造货币，并用它们购买长期债券，目的是降低其收益率。迫在眉睫的问题是，随着央行提高利率以应对通货膨胀，它们不得不支付更多的准备金。然而，他们收到的债券息票支付保持不变。出售债券来阻止资金外流无济于事，因为它们的收益远低于成本。账面损失将会具体化。

相反，政策制定者正在尽最大努力掩盖这个问题。欧洲央行于 7 月 28 日宣布，出于金融稳定原因，将停止对银行持有的最低现金余额支付利息，这实际上是对银行体系征收隐性税。 （“我们感到失望，而且有些惊讶，”德意志银行表示，该银行每年将损失超过 2 亿欧元，即 2.2 亿美元。） 与英格兰银行不同，美联储不会接受政府的注资。相反，当美联储再次开始盈利时，它将把它们装进自己的口袋，而不是送到财政部。只有在央行收回目前损失的现金后，付款才会恢复。到目前为止，美联储欠自己约800亿美元。

这些策略并没有改变这样一个事实：大规模的量化宽松减记正在增加脆弱的政府预算的负担，而政府预算因金融危机、covid-19大流行和人口老龄化而捉襟见肘。由于大流行时期的许多量化宽松政策最终都产生了反作用，因此损失更加令人尴尬。各国央行在有必要的很长一段时间后仍继续购买债券：美联储在 2022 年 3 月购买了最后一批国债，当时通胀率已达 8.5%。不久之后，政策制定者意识到他们实施了过多的刺激措施并大幅加息。央行因通胀持续而亏损只是它们显得愚蠢的另一个原因。

最近的经验是否意味着下次经济确实需要刺激时应该放弃量化宽松？央行行长应根据具体情况进行指导。

他们应该遵循的第一条规则是在金融危机期间不要退缩。 2008年底，由于市场失灵以及美联储充当最后贷款人，美联储的资产负债表规模翻了一番。它几乎在 2020 年春天重演了这一伎俩，当时疫情的爆发导致投资者“争先恐后地抢钱”。当市场恐慌时吸纳资产更有可能产生利润而不是损失，但即使这种干预措施亏损，也是值得的。为了避免 1930 年代式的金融灾难，即使是数千亿美元也是值得付出的代价，这场灾难之后失业率飙升，今天将造成数十万亿美元的损失。

当市场平静时，量化宽松刺激增长和通胀的力量就更难判断。一篇文献综述计算出的中值估计是，购买相当于GDP 10% 的债券只会使 10 年期政府债券收益率降低半个百分点。此外，央行本身就是许多这些估计的来源，并且有夸大影响的动机：研究人员发现，报告量化宽松对增长影响更大的论文作者随后会享受更多晋升。因此，购买债券的真正经济效益很差，这是有道理的。当然，最近在日本也是如此，日本央行浪费了大量资金来捍卫债券市场挂钩，结果却是解除它并承受损失。

因此，第二条规则应该是只有当所有其他选择都真正用尽时才诉诸量化宽松。即使利率降至零且无法进一步降息，央行也可以明确其长期保持低利率的意图——这一承诺可能会因量化宽松而得到加强，但几乎不依赖于量化宽松。政府可以通过减税或增加支出作为刺激措施，就像他们在大流行期间大规模所做的那样。至关重要的是，他们可以通过发行长期债务为财政刺激提供资金，与量化宽松创建的储备不同，如果利率上升，长期债务不会导致预算紧张。购买债券应该保留在紧急武器库中，以防万一。但未来央行应该不会那么好动。 ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 19:13:44 GMT /内容/bd5o4fv0ekgr022g2fl8r9baa711urlr https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/07/31/quantitative-easing-has-cost-hundreds-of-billions-of-dollars The world’s worst central banker retires

在大多数国家，如果货币贬值 95%，中央银行行长就会被解雇。 黎巴嫩的情况并非如此，到 2021 年底，黎巴嫩已陷入严重的金融危机两年。长期与美元挂钩的里拉汇率已跌至 27,500 里拉。总理纳吉布·米卡提 (Najib Mikati) 被问及是否该更换长期担任黎巴嫩银行 ( Banque du Liban ) 行长的时候了。他的回答很明确：“战争期间不会更换军官”。

战争仍在激烈进行，但即使是黎巴嫩的政客似乎也有其局限性。目前里拉兑美元汇率为 90,000 里拉。自 2018 年以来， GDP萎缩了 40%。在经营了 30 年的债务之后，Riad Salameh 终于在 7 月 31日失业了。尚未宣布永久替代者。但米卡蒂先生仍然拒绝延长任期。

支持者曾称萨拉梅先生为“魔术师”，因为他在一个不稳定的国家保持了稳定的货币。与所有魔术一样，萨拉梅先生的幻觉要求观众不要看得太仔细：他的故事不仅讲述了个人的失败和耻辱，还讲述了一个政客拒绝对政策负责的国家。

萨拉梅先生于 1993 年由黎巴嫩内战后首任总理拉菲克·哈里里 (Rafik Hariri) 任命。他们共同建立了一个依赖大量外资流入来为巨额赤字融资（2014 年经常项目缺口达到GDP的 26%）并维持盯住货币的经济体。在鼎盛时期，该国银行业持有的存款价值是该国国内生产总值的四倍。

该计划于 2015 年开始陷入困境，因为地区不稳定和油价暴跌损害了资金流入。为了吸引新存款，萨拉梅启动了一项名为“金融工程”的计划。银行支付高于市场的利率从商业银行借入美元，而商业银行又向储户提供慷慨的利率。

一时间，人人皆大欢喜：央行增加了总储备，而银行及其客户则享受了可观的利润。当权者没有人提出问题。萨拉梅先生的一位前副手表示，州长从未将“金融工程”问题提交给央行中央委员会进行辩论。议会也没有进行任何监督。

2018年，一些银行家和经济学家试图敲响警钟。萨拉梅先生宣称里拉alf khair意为“千种恩惠”，是黎巴嫩的最高级货币。全国大部分人都相信他的话。

然而一年后，商业银行存款开始萎缩。不再有足够的新资金来偿还旧债务。到 2019 年 12 月，就连萨拉梅先生也无法再假装了。里拉兑美元汇率已跌至 2,000 里拉。当一名电视记者问他会在哪里停止时，他耸耸肩：“没有人知道。”

但没有人敢除掉他。萨拉梅先生与黎巴嫩的政治、商业和媒体精英以及美国和法国等强大的外国赞助人建立了密切的联系。他可以自由地颁布一系列疯狂的法令，为补贴提供资金，实行资本管制，并试图管理汇率。它们损害了储户的利益，即使货币崩溃，该国的外汇储备也从 2018 年的 310 亿美元降至 100 亿美元。

最明显的政策错误是 Sayrafa，这是一个电子外汇平台，旨在遏制不断增长的黑市并阻止里拉的剧烈波动。实际上，它是送给银行、进口商和其他富有精英的赠品。 Sayrafa 费率始终落后于黑市费率约 20%。任何有权访问该平台的人都可以以折扣价购买美元并在平行市场上转售。世界银行 5 月份估计，这种往返套利已产生 25 亿美元的利润（由银行承担）。

并不是说其他​​人追求更好的想法。前总理哈桑·迪亚布起草了一份不错的救援计划，但遭到银行家和议员的阻挠。在与国际货币基金组织进行了三年的救助谈判后，议会尚未通过黎巴嫩僵尸银行的重组计划。即使是一些糟糕的想法，比如通过抛售国有资产来对银行进行资本重组，也没有进展到无以复加的地步。

黎巴嫩议会有四名副省长，根据黎巴嫩的宗派权力分享规则，他们来自四个不同的教派。 7月初，他们威胁说，如果萨拉梅先生的任期结束后没有继任者，他们将辞职。此后他们做出了让步，并提出了一些合理的政策建议，其中包括废除 Sayrafa 计划。

然而，他们提出的大部分建议都需要政客的同意，而政客们在任何事情上都无法达成一致。尽管黎巴嫩议会曾 12 次尝试选出总统，但自 10 月以来黎巴嫩一直没有选出总统。权力强大的情报局长阿巴斯·易卜拉欣 (Abbas Ibrahim) 于三月结束了任期。他也没有被取代。另一个空缺即将在一月份出现，陆军参谋长约瑟夫·奥恩(Joseph Aoun)即将退休。国家正在崩溃，无人能主宰。

至于萨拉梅先生，他的退休生活不太可能平静。比利时、法国、德国、列支敦士登、卢森堡和瑞士当局都在调查他的腐败行为。他被指控从央行窃取了高达 3.3 亿美元的资金。调查人员称，部分资金存入了他兄弟的瑞士银行账户，其他资金则用于在欧洲各地购买房产。 （萨拉梅先生否认了这些指控，称他于 1993 年带着 2300 万美元辞去美林证券的工作，并明智地进行了投资。）

五月，一名法国法官因未能出席听证会而发出国际逮捕令。德国也向国际刑警组织发出了红色通缉令。黎巴嫩法律并不要求引渡他，许多观察家认为该国司法机构过于政治化，无法在国内起诉他。尽管如此，正如一位前同事直言不讳地说，“他被讨厌了”。对于他的最后一招，魔术师可能希望完成一场消失的表演。 ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 18:53:32 GMT /内容/jtvus8p92mg5r4r9sqp9jb28mieqi6vd https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/07/31/the-worlds-worst-central-banker-retires What you learn on a 24-hour train journey east through Europe

拿一张欧洲地图，找到巴黎，然后画一条向东的线。一整天一夜你能走多远？只要火车组合正确，再加上足够的耐心，就可以穿越法国和德国，然后穿越奥地利、匈牙利，最后进入罗马尼亚。该国第二大城市克卢日-纳波卡距离巴黎直线距离为 1,597 公里（992 英里），而蜿蜒的轨道距离为 2,100 公里。火车上的景色——有的快速行驶，有的缓慢前行——提供了沉思的空间。从纽约市到堪萨斯州托皮卡的旅程与美国巴黎克卢日的旅程相似，需要 32 小时；在中国，从上海到成都的 1,651 公里行程需要不到 12 小时。以下是您在 23 小时 59 分钟内凝视火车窗外对欧洲的发现。

参观一些地方有助于消除人们对它们的刻板印象。当火车于早上 7 点 20 分离开巴黎东站时，巴黎人正在排队购买星巴克：对于懒惰的法国人来说，他们对美国进口产品持谨慎态度。

乘坐高速列车穿越法国东部是一项对比研究。一方面，您可以感受到共和国的全面现代化力量，它在四十多年前首次安装了高铁。但在香槟地区——火车以超过 300 公里/小时的速度呼啸而过——同样专横的国家将 17 世纪的起泡酒酿造工艺编入法典。法国人既要求进步，又要求时间停滞不前。

说到铁路旅行，从法国出发，速度都在下降：在欧洲越远的东部，火车的速度就越慢。从巴黎到斯特拉斯堡仅需不到两个小时，全程 395 公里。继续前往法兰克福只需同样的时间即可走完一半的路程。再往东走，事情会变得更慢。

鉴于如今欧盟大部分地区都可以免护照旅行，很难判断一个国家从哪里开始，另一个国家从哪里开始。在火车站站台，法国尖锐口音被日耳曼变音符号取代（接下来会出现更多异国口音：Tápiószecső、Măgeşti）。跨越边境最明显的标志是火车车厢里的每个人都收到来自移动电话运营商的欢迎他们来到德国的短信。

如果您需要换车，请在小镇进行：步行穿过站台通常就足够了。像法兰克福这样的地方在城市的两端都有车站。除了欧洲中央银行办公室外的巨型欧元符号 (€) 雕塑之外，它们之间的步行道几乎没有什么值得注意的地方——算不上什么世界级的景点。

德国的西翼是法国地理学家曾经称之为“蓝色香蕉”的一部分，这是一个不连续的大都市，从利物浦经阿姆斯特丹延伸到米兰。如果可以选择，那就在德国火车上吃饭。他们的餐车配有豪华的红色皮革长椅，穿着制服的工作人员将食物放在真正的瓷器上。 Linseneintopf是一种美味的小扁豆和香肠炖菜，是旅行者的丰盛美食。当地的比特堡啤酒被倒入其适当品牌的玻璃杯中，而不是塑料杯中。

从其他方面来说，德国是欧洲长途旅行的致命弱点。很少有泛大陆旅行可以避免它。然而，它对财政廉洁的痴迷导致其基础设施破旧不堪，其中包括铁路线。去年， 德国铁路公司有三分之一的列车晚点——这又打破了人们的刻板印象。预订转接铁路旅行是一种信仰行为。当狡猾的信号迫使驾驶员定期猛踩刹车时，轨道系统的劣质就显现出来了。这对餐车造成了严重破坏。 “抓紧你的食物！”服务员尖叫道：“拿住你的杯子！”

长途飞行弥补损失的时间；长途火车会积累它。晚点30分钟起飞的飞机可能会准时降落；在火车上，您最终会休息一个小时，因此很可能会错过在维也纳本应舒适的转机。

当您靠近奥地利边境时，多瑙河映入眼帘。轨道沿着它延伸600公里。幸运的是，德国铁路公司的延误也与其他运营商相匹配。晚点一小时抵达维也纳——开往克卢日的火车比原定出发的时间晚了一分钟——发现罗马尼亚国家铁路公司也无法准时运行列车，这让人松了口气。

出于对碳排放飞机的担忧，欧洲夜间列车重新兴起。目前维也纳是非洲大陆唯一的主要枢纽：沙发界的迪拜。每天晚上，火车从内陆国家奥地利出发，前往欧洲各地的海岸线，从波罗的海到北海和地中海。

在维也纳东南部的平原上，风力涡轮机排列得非常密集，就像一把刷毛竖起来的发刷。桅杆上的红灯在夕阳的映衬下闪烁。当火车缓缓驶入匈牙利时，可以看到的涡轮机越来越少，匈牙利政府将绿色环保问题视为乌托邦。

从维也纳到克卢日的票价约为 227 列伊（50 美元），再加上单床舱票价的两倍。这里设有一间连接浴室，但……不提供食物。事实证明，这些天从维也纳到克卢日的夜间列车上没有餐车。德国铁路：一切都可以原谅。在布达佩斯停留的时间太短，无法找到炖牛肉。

脱轨

您可以在匈牙利和罗马尼亚之间找到欧洲最后的真正边界之一，该边界尚未获准进入申根区。运气不好：火车在夜深人静时抵达边境。如果您认为匈牙利边防人员在凌晨 3:15 心情低落，那么请等到凌晨 3:30 与罗马尼亚边防人员见面。

中欧正在与富裕的西方国家趋同。但在特兰西瓦尼亚，这个过程感觉很缓慢。 4G手机功能完美，但你可以看到马在土地上劳作，仿佛回到了另一个世纪。 Train stations are plastered with EU flags, evidence of “structural funds” past and present.

If you have a crumpled shirt in your luggage, hang it up when you depart. The vibrations of the journey will eliminate creases better than any iron. As the train arrives, adjust your watch one hour forward, to 8:19. Welcome to Cluj. ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 18:23:44 GMT /content/h09jjla4gq10ge5gfndobnnqgks82gas https://www.economist.com/europe/2023/07/31/what-you-learn-on-a-24-hour-train-journey-east-through-europe Horrifying numbers of Americans will not make it to old age

W alk into the Rebound recovery centre, on the Main Street of Hazard, Kentucky, a small Appalachian coalmining town, and you will get an instantly friendly welcome. Yet the stories you hear are bleak. On a white board at the end of the room, across from the sofas, the names of former clients who have died of overdoses in the past few years are listed. Though the town has a population of just 5,000, there are at least 20 names. James Colwell, a 33-year-old former heroin addict, who has been clean for eight years, and who now works at the centre, says that the toll keeps growing. Heroin addiction is actually less common than it used to be, he says, thanks in part to the proliferation of treatment. The problem is that “everyone is on meth. And they're putting fentanyl in the pills.” The very next day, he says, he is going to the funeral of a middle-aged former nurse who died after accidentally taking fentanyl, a powerful synthetic opiate.

Hazard was named after Oliver Hazard Perry, a naval hero of the war of 1812, rather than for its character. Yet it is an appallingly dangerous place to live. In 2019, even before the deadly pandemic, the town and surrounding area, Perry County, came sixth-from-bottom out of America's 3,142 counties on a measure of age-standardised mortality. At every age, people were far more likely to die . Opiates, which began to spread around 25 years ago, when doctors prescribed them to former coalminers for chronic pain, are a large part of the reason. But heart attacks are also more common. So are traffic deaths, something local police put down to the refusal of people driving on the winding mountain roads to wear seat belts. Last year the town flooded, and mountain walls slid onto houses. And guns are everywhere. It all adds up to a lot of death. On average, people in Perry could expect to live to just 69 in 2019, compared with 79 in America as a whole.

In the past 20 years, on economic measures, America has outperformed other rich countries. Over that period, median wages grew by 25%, compared with just 17% in Germany. Managers at Buc-ee's, a Texas-based chain of stores, can make more than experienced doctors earn in Britain. But on a more fundamental measure of wellness—how long people live—America is falling behind. To its detractors, this is a cause for schadenfreude. “Many people say it is easier to buy a gun than baby formula in the US ,” gloated a statement released by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs last year, which also pointed to declining life expectancy in general. In the past few years, according to some estimates, life expectancy in China overtook that in America. For Americans, that ought to be a more serious source of introspection than it is.

According to a study by Jessica Ho of the University of Southern California, published last year, which looked at 18 high-income countries, from a fairly average position in 1980, by 2018 America had fallen to dead last on life expectancy. In the 1960s Americans could expect to live seven or eight years longer than people from Portugal, the country in the study that now has the next-lowest life expectancy. By 2018 they could expect to live over a year less. Areas like eastern Kentucky, which have been worst hit, help illustrate why.

In the past three years, all of those figures have probably worsened, owing partly to the coronavirus. A study by KFF , a non-profit organisation, found that by 2021, in the worst of the pandemic, Americans could expect to live fully six years less than people in other rich countries (see chart 1). The virus reduced American life expectancy by just over 2.5 years; in peer countries, the average decline was two months. Though the virus now kills far fewer people, overall mortality rates remain elevated. Death caused by opiates, car crashes and murder have all increased. The pandemic underlined something that has been true for decades: America does not do a very good job of keeping its people safe.

What is killing Americans so much more? Ask almost any public-health expert, and they will point to the huge burden of poor health. Tom Frieden, a former head of the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention ( CDC ), explains that progress on reducing mortality from chronic diseases has stalled. In the 20th century laws helped improve public health dramatically, bringing about massive reductions in smoking and air pollution. Cholesterol levels tumbled, too. But now the rising burden of obesity is countering the benefits. Roughly 11% of Americans suffer from diabetes, against a figure of just 6% in France; two-fifths of American adults are clinically obese, double the rate across the OECD , a club of mostly rich countries. “Despite the fact we're making progress in some areas, we're going backwards overall,” says Dr Frieden.

But this does not fully not explain why America is doing so much worse than elsewhere. Obesity and diabetes are rising almost everywhere; rates have been higher in America for decades. And indeed, increasing access to the best health care is one of the few ways in which Americans are catching up with, or even leaping ahead of, people in other rich countries. Cancer-survival rates in America are the highest in the world. Of sufferers of prostate cancer, in America 98% survive for at least ten years. In Britain the figure is only 78%. Access to health care has improved greatly. Last year the proportion of Americans without health insurance fell to its lowest-ever level.

The problem lies outside the doctor's clinic. Covid-19 aside, in recent years it is rising violent deaths that explain America's divergence from the rest of the rich world (see chart 2).

The facts of death

To quote William Farr, an early pioneer in medical statistics, “Death is a fact. All else is inference.” Life-expectancy estimates are made by extrapolating probabilities from the total raw death rate at every age each year. This means that deaths at younger ages have bigger effects. Something that shaves a year off everybody's life has a similar effect on life-expectancy estimates as something that leads to the premature death of one baby in 80. And what is most shocking about America is how many people—especially men—die young.

In 2021, 38,307 Americans aged between 15 and 24 died. In England and Wales the equivalent figure was just 2,185. As a share of the population, roughly three times as many Americans of that age group died in 2021 as English and Welsh. Ms Ho's research suggests that Americans are more likely to die than people in other rich countries at every age up to 85. If you make it to that advanced age, your chances of surviving longer are roughly the same as elsewhere.

Even in 2021, as covid deaths soared, increases in what the CDC calls “unintentional injuries” accounted for 16% of the decline in life expectancy they estimated happened that year over 2020. Opiates are a huge part of that. In 2021, according to the CDC , 107,000 people died of drug overdoses, the vast majority linked to heroin or fentanyl. No other rich country comes close to this rate of drug deaths (though Scotland is not that far off). And in 2021 around 43,000 Americans died in car crashes, which was the highest figure since 2005 (the number fell a bit last year); in Germany the rate was a quarter of America's. Around 26,000 were murdered, against just 300 in Italy.

In fact, almost any horrible death you can think of, Americans are more likely to suffer it. Over 5,000 people died in 2021 in workplace accidents, up by 9% on the previous year; the figure in Britain was 123. Nearly 4,000 people died in fires, the highest number in close to 20 years, making for a death rate of nearly twice that of western Europe. Americans are more than twice as likely to drown as the Dutch (though the French, with their long holidays by the ocean, drown at even higher rates).

For an explanation, a look at America's geography is revealing. According to Laura Dwyer-Lindgren, an academic with the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington in Seattle, who analysed decades of mortality data by county, the national trend of stagnant life expectancy reveals huge regional variation (see map). In a place like Hazard, in eastern Kentucky, life expectancy is lower now than it was in 1980. In a place like Manhattan, or some wealthier counties of Colorado, it has increased by not much less than anywhere in Europe. According to Ms Dwyer-Lindgren's data, somebody in their early 60s living in Manhattan is four times less likely to die in a given year than somebody in Hazard. The highest death rates are in a band that runs across the south and south-east of the country. The lowest are increasingly concentrated on the coasts, and in rich, mountain retreats, like Colorado.

This partly reflects diverging economies. Eastern Kentucky is desperately poor. Many people turned to opiates after losing their jobs in coalmining, says Tom Vicini, of Operation UNITE , an NGO which tries to tackle addiction in the region. “If you look at the community that I live in now, it's changed drastically over the last 20 or 30 years, from a thriving coal industry to….now almost no jobs,” he says. Other places that have suffered as badly are also dirt poor—they include Indian reservations in South Dakota, which never had many jobs to begin with, and rural parts of the Mississippi Delta where agricultural work has dried up. But poverty cannot entirely explain what is happening. Hazard is not that poor by international standards. Next to the Rebound Centre is a hip coffee shop and a smart toy shop; the streets are lined with expensive cars. Nor is death limited to the poor. Across the southern United States people on average incomes die at higher rates than even the very poor in New York City.

The problem is not only that America has become less safe (though in some ways it has). It is also that other countries have improved and America has not. Take, for example, car crashes. Calculations by the Urban Institute, a think-tank, show that in the 1990s French people died in crashes at a rate slightly higher than Americans—and per mile driven, at a rate roughly double. Now, however, Americans are more than twice as likely to die in car crashes. Over the past two decades European roads have been redesigned with roundabouts, speed cameras and pedestrian barriers. American ones have been widened. Other countries have tightened up gun ownership. America has expanded it. Even opiates stand out. In the 1980s Europe also suffered a devastating epidemic of heroin abuse when heavy industry declined. Unlike America, it quickly made substitutes such as methadone widely available, and did not have another.

Lethal politics

Could this help explain America's drifting politics? A generation ago Ronald Reagan won re-election with an optimistic slogan, “It's morning again in America”, depicting people living happy, sunny lives. In May Donald Trump launched his own version—”It's mourning again in America”—featuring fentanyl, transgender athletes and a doddering Joe Biden. Mr Trump thrived in the areas with the highest death rates, and in particular among white working-class voters, for whom death rates have increased most. In places where people die less, the Democrats are generally doing better. Katherine Cramer, a political scientist from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, suggests that much of Mr Trump's success is driven by “resentment”, particularly that of white rural people who feel left behind relative to people in big cities. Dying so much earlier would seem a legitimate cause for resentment.

Yet Mr Trump's solutions hardly seem likely to fix things. Matthew Ruther, a geographer at the University of Louisville, argues that the problem is in part cultural. “The social contract is different here than it is with other countries,” he says. Americans, he suggests, have a strong belief in personal responsibility, and do not expect the state to shield them from poor decisions.

A drive around Kentucky tends to support the impression that personal choices do indeed play a part. Your correspondent counted a dozen motorcyclists on his visit. Not one was wearing a helmet. Half of passenger deaths in car crashes involve somebody who is not wearing a seat belt. A visit to a gun shop in London, a town around 50 miles west of Hazard, is also revealing. Asked about opiate deaths in eastern Kentucky, the owner laments the toll but then says: “They choose to do it! I guess they just think it won't be them.”

“The mentality in the United States is to pull yourself up by your bootstraps. Yeah no they can't,” says Barbara Ramp, whose son Alec died of a heroin overdose nearly a decade ago, at the age of 20. She describes how Alec was told not to seek methadone treatment for his addiction, because he should focus on getting truly clean. “Our government just doesn't seem to be protecting people,” she says. Some Republicans suggest that it is not the government's job to protect people. “It's worth [it] to have a cost of, unfortunately, some gun deaths every single year so that we can have the Second Amendment,” said Charlie Kirk, a prominent conservative activist, in April. Live free and die.

In fact, Americans do still generally see protection from death as the responsibility of government. The problem is that they often search for outside enemies to defeat, rather than solutions that would help Americans help themselves. To combat fentanyl, politicians such as Dan Crenshaw, a congressman, have proposed launching military strikes against drug gangs in Mexico. Yet the politicians take years to implement more direct life-saving measures. Until April this year, in Kentucky fentanyl testing-strips—which can save lives by alerting drug users to contaminated wares—were classed as illegal “drug paraphernalia”. A few other states also legalised the strips this year, including hard-hit ones such as Mississippi, Ohio and Pennsylvania. But they remain illegal in several others, including Texas, Mr Crenshaw's home state.

Reducing the death toll will take more than bombing Mexico. It will also take a politics that is more sympathetic to human frailty, and at times more willing to inconvenience people. Change can happen. Under Pete Buttigieg, the transport secretary, federal money for highway improvements made available under the Infrastructure Act increasingly comes with requirements that roads be redeveloped to be safer to drive on. That mostly means making drivers go more slowly. Last year, a modest gun-control bill that expanded background checks was passed by Congress with bipartisan support, despite the opposition of the National Rifle Association, which argued it will inconvenience law-abiding gun purchasers. For tens of thousands of Americans a year, such changes cannot happen soon enough. ■

More Americans than ever report a disability

Yet they are more likely to have a job than before the pandemic

Read the full findings from this year's liveability index here .

E GYPT'S GOVERNMENT worries that its citizens may get trapped in their lifts. Frequent power outages in Cairo, the capital, during the sweltering summer months mean that such miserable confinement is not an unlikely occurrence. Like many other cities in the Middle East and Africa, Cairo's wobbly infrastructure makes it a difficult place to live. Food inflation is running at 66%, and members of the middle class are sliding into poverty . That reality is reflected in findings by EIU , our sister company, and its liveable cities index. See where Cairo and other cities in the Middle East and Africa ranked in our map below.

EIU ’s global index judges 173 cities on five categories: stability, health care, culture and environment, education, and infrastructure. Notably, some big cities like Khartoum, in Sudan, and Baghdad, in Iraq, are not included in the index. Despite the general low rankings of cities in the Middle East and north Africa, liveability is generally improving. Its cities received an average score of 61, up from 58 last year. The score for sub-Saharan Africa (the world's least liveable region) rose from 50 last year to 54 in 2023. Both regions saw improvements in cities at the bottom of the rankings. Algiers and Lagos—both in energy-exporting countries—benefited from rising energy prices, allowing their governments to pump money into public services and infrastructure.

Abu Dhabi retained its top spot in the region, thanks to good scores for its infrastructure and stability. Dubai, another city in the United Arab Emirates, was a close second. Tel Aviv in Israel, once a beacon of democracy in the region, came third. But its score was dragged down by increased instability—in large part because of unrest spurred by the government's bid to limit the powers of the country's independent judiciary.

There were other notable shifts across the Middle East and north Africa. Several cities in Saudi Arabia improved their score in the culture and environment category, which measures such things as the availability of sporting and cultural offerings. In culture, Saudi Arabia once lagged behind the likes of Cairo and Casablanca. Now it is trying to establish itself as the region's media hub, pumping money into home-grown films and lavish music concerts. Even more notable is its foray into sports: it has acquired several European footballers to play in its domestic league, including Cristiano Ronaldo in late 2022. In June of this year it reportedly invested $3bn to merge its upstart golf tournament with America's PGA Tour and Europe's DP World Tour, the biggest in the sport. But Saudi's stability scores remained unchanged. Its rulers continue to stifle any opposition.

As in the past several years, war-ravaged Damascus, Syria's capital, scored the lowest of any city in the world. Although Bashar al-Assad , the country's brutal dictator, is no longer a pariah in the Middle East, his gradual return to the international stage has not led to any improvements in the living standards of his people. It is not likely that will change anytime soon.

Cities in sub-Saharan Africa didn't fare so well either. Johannesburg, South Africa's biggest city, is still the most liveable place on the continent south of the Sahara, but it dropped seven places in the rankings. ( Cape Town , the country's much-improved second city, is not part of the index.) The public sector there is failing: those with the means pay for private alternatives. Blackouts are more frequent there than they were last year. Its residents probably worry about getting stuck in a lift even more than Cairenes. ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 17:35:45 GMT /content/culab42hjn6pd0nkr9cc0cpanoofd20e https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/07/31/the-worlds-least-liveable-cities-are-showing-some-signs-of-improvement How to reduce American carnage

A T HIS INAUGURATION in 2017 Donald Trump rejected the uplifting vision of America that such ceremonies usually extol. Instead he warned of “American carnage”, painting a picture of industrial devastation and lives stolen through crime, gangs and drugs. In office Mr Trump hardly managed to change the country for the better. But on “American carnage” he had a point: too many Americans are dying too young.

The numbers are shocking (as our article describes). A study last year of life expectancy in 18 rich countries showed that America fell from a middling position in the 1980s to last place in 2018—and that was before the covid-19 pandemic took a disproportionate toll on Americans. To some extent this reflects striking gains in life expectancy elsewhere. Take Portugal, the next-from-bottom country in the ranking, which has thrived within the European Union. In the 1960s the average American could expect to live at least seven years longer than the average Portuguese; by 2018 it was a year less. It is stunning that on such an important measure America has fallen behind a country that remains only a third as rich per head. In terms of life expectancy, America may even have been overtaken by China.

By far the biggest killers in America are heart disease and cancer, despite some of the world's best cancer care. That reflects unhealthy lifestyles as well as shortcomings in disease prevention and unequal access to health care. Obesity is a global problem, but America's rate is double the rich-country OECD average.

The most striking divergence between America and its peers, however, with an outsize impact on life expectancy, is in violent deaths, especially of young men. The country's death rate among 15- to 24-year-olds is three times that in England and Wales. Two of the causes are familiar. In 2019 the murder rate from guns was fully 22 times that in the EU . A 25-year opioid epidemic has killed more than 650,000 Americans. But there is more to America's outlier status than guns and fentanyl. Road deaths, which killed nearly 43,000 people in America last year, are about four times the rate in Germany. Pick almost any type of calamitous death—drowning, fire, work accidents—and America's relative record looks dire.

One way to explain this is that, collectively, Americans have come to a different conclusion about the proper balance between individual freedom and state protections. This is overly fatalistic. Yes, Americans are a rugged lot, fond of individual responsibility and wary of government intervention. But that has always been so. It does not explain the slippage of recent years.

Moreover, not all Americans are equally at risk. The poor are particularly vulnerable. Startling falls in life expectancy have occurred mostly in left-behind parts of the South and the central heartlands, rather than on the coasts. Such variation is not unique: in Britain , life expectancy for men between a posh and a poor part of London just 10km (six miles) apart varies from 92 years to 74. In richer areas of America, whether on the coasts or in the more prosperous counties of Colorado, people have typically experienced the same sort of gains in life expectancy as Europeans. It makes little sense to draw sweeping conclusions about people's preferences when outcomes are so unequal.

What can be done? Some big things are politically hard but worth arguing for nonetheless. From serious gun controls to more enlightened drugs policies (less war, more decriminalisation), Congress could make a difference. Liran Einav and Amy Finkelstein, two health economists, argue in a new book for basic universal health insurance financed by income taxes that would bring coverage for the 30m Americans who still lack it—in the hope that one day politicians will be ready to consider them seriously. That would help, too.

Many ways to save many lives

In the meantime, Americans could do lots of small things that, added together, would amount to something bigger. On health care, there is no good reason why ten states, including poor ones such as Alabama and Mississippi, should keep rejecting Obamacare's incentives to extend Medicaid coverage to some of their most vulnerable residents. To reduce the slaughter on America's roads, why not ensure that more people wear motorcycle helmets or seat belts? Half of America's passenger deaths involve people who are not strapped in. At the very least, troopers should enforce speed limits. Some policies, like building roundabouts instead of intersections, cost little and hardly impinge on personal liberties. As for the opioid crisis, local government should expand access to treatments for addicts and make test strips for fentanyl widely available so that people know if they're about to take a potentially lethal substance (absurdly, several states, including Texas, still treat such strips as illegal drug paraphernalia).

For such things to come about, Americans need to recognise just how many of their compatriots' lives are being squandered. Too often politicians have been slow to do so and, as a result, America has come to tolerate an obscene level of early deaths. Only after the shock and shame of yet another mass shooting, at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, last year, did Congress muster the will to pass modest new gun controls. A proper sense of alarm at other kinds of needless loss may help bring about measures to keep more Americans alive for longer. That way the country could start to curb the carnage. ■

; Mon, 31 Jul 2023 10:23:15 GMT /content/g6hasihkkrlrpum1vfthtrcmgtjshomf https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/07/31/nigers-army-has-toppled-its-president-now-what Seth Berkley on how to improve global access to vaccines

O NE OF THE few positive legacies of the covid-19 pandemic is the pace and scale of scientific innovation that it triggered. The world received vaccines at record-breaking speed, the result of work based on revolutions in biotechnology, artificial intelligence, gene-editing and computing. We already have two vaccines that can prevent certain forms of cancer. More may emerge by the end of the decade, along with new ones capable of targeting heart disease, acne and a range of tropical diseases. These could save countless millions more lives.

So if ever there was a time to level the global-health playing field, it is now. This has been my mission for more than four decades, and for the past 12 years as chief executive of Gavi, the public-private global-health partnership that I am about to leave. As Gavi's first board chair, Nelson Mandela, put it, life or death for a child should not be dependent on where they are born. But although science can help close many of the gaps in global-health equity, some of the biggest remaining barriers are economic and geopolitical.

Take the pandemic. Science may have developed and manufactured covid vaccines in less than 11 months—and not just one, but over time dozens of them—but most of the early doses went to rich countries. If distribution is left to market dynamics alone, poorer countries will almost always get less. People in such places will either be priced out of the market or not even considered viable customers by profit-focused manufacturers, as was historically the case for a wide range of vaccines. In the case of covid-19, vaccine nationalism and trade barriers also played a part in restricting the global delivery of jabs.

Despite these travails, more than 56% of people in lower-income countries eligible for free doses via COVAX , a multilateral vaccines-access initiative, have received at least two covid-vaccine doses—not far behind the global average of 65%. More than 80% of children worldwide now receive all three doses of the “ DPT ” vaccine against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough) and tetanus. All this is because their fate has not been left entirely to markets. Organisations such as Gavi exist for this reason: to address vaccine-market failures.

Poorer countries often used to have to wait for more than a decade to access new vaccines. Gavi changed that, not through science but economics. By pooling demand from lower-income countries, thus providing manufacturers with long-term guarantees, we were in effect able to create new markets in these countries. At the same time we encouraged other manufacturers to enter these markets, or to develop new vaccines, stimulating innovation and competition, helping to bring prices down and cutting the time it took for poorer countries to get access to vaccines to within just a year or two of the wait for rich countries. As a result, the number of Gavi's vaccine suppliers has increased from five in 2000 (mostly from Europe or North America) to 24 today (more than half of which are based in emerging markets).

When the pandemic struck, COVAX showed that it was possible to deliver the first jab in a developing country just over a month after the first mass vaccination in a high-income country (Britain)—although large volumes were delayed for many countries for up to nine months.

The worry now is that with covid-19 no longer seen as a global health emergency, the world will slip back into the neglectful habits of the past. To avoid this, we need to anticipate potential failures or bottlenecks in future pandemic markets. That means building on the mechanisms developed during this pandemic and ensuring that contingent finance is in place, enabling donors to speed up funding to Gavi in response to future health threats. It also means investing in long-term market solutions to prevent protectionist export controls from impeding global supply chains. For example, investing in vaccine-manufacturing in poorer regions—particularly Africa, which currently produces less than 0.1% of global supply—could help to make access more equitable during future health crises, even in the face of national vaccine-hoarding.

Building vaccine-producing capacity in such regions will take time. It requires the creation of a sustainable vaccine ecosystem that includes manufacturing facilities, subsidies to defray some of the high initial costs of building them, specialised workforces, rigorous and independent regulatory systems, and sustained demand for routine vaccines. Gavi is currently working with Africa CDC , a public-health agency of the African Union, and its Partnership for African Vaccine Manufacturing to develop a financial instrument that could help new manufacturers to compete.

We are now in a better position than ever to level the global-health playing field. In June 2021 leaders from the G 7 called on scientific, governmental and industry experts to ensure that in the future vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics are available at affordable prices within 100 days of a pandemic threat being identified. This “100 Days Mission” is a welcome aspiration, but accelerating the science must not be the sole focus. Mechanisms are needed to overcome economic and political barriers to equal access.

With a wave of exciting new jabs coming our way, from malaria vaccines to inoculations against respiratory syncytial virus and perhaps tuberculosis and Group B Streptococcus (and, hopefully, some day HIV ), there is no excuse to continue to deny or delay access for poorer countries. After decades of working in this field, I have great faith that when science delivers, so, with the right kind of intervention, can markets. ■

Seth Berkley is the chief executive of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. He will step down on August 3rd.

Nothing seems to be able to dent America's labour market these days. A new analysis finds that the number of American adults reporting that they have a disability has risen sharply since the pandemic—but has not made them less likely to work. The share of Americans reporting that they have “serious difficulty” in certain daily tasks has risen sharply since the pandemic, to nearly 8% for those aged 16 to 64, and 13% for those aged 16 and over—a record high. Precisely why the pandemic has boosted disability rates is unclear, though the types of disabilities that are on the rise suggest that long covid is to blame.
